trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of three different breakfast meals with varying glycaemic load and dairy composition on cognition and satiety in healthy children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of three different breakfast meals with varying glycaemic load and dairy composition on cognition and satiety in healthy children

interventions.interventions: Three breakfast meals that differ in glycaemic load (GL) and dairy composition. Meal 1 (GL ~ 36/low dairy) - 70g white bread, 10g margarine, 10g vegemite (or 30g diet jam), 200ml sweetened fruit drink, 100ml water Meal 2 (GL ~ 27/medium dairy) - 35g white bread, 100g yoghurt, 20g cheese, 5g vegemite (or 15g diet jam), 100ml sweetened fruit drink, 100ml water Meal 3 (GL ~ 21/high dairy) - 35g white bread, 100g yoghurt, 20g cheese, 5g vegemite (or 15g jam), 100ml reduced fat milk, 100ml water. Food and beverage intake is not controlled for other meals, however there is an overnight 'wash-out' period between interventions.
interventions.comparator: No control - crossover design. Each participant will have all 3 meals (as described above) over 3 consecutive days

primaryOutcome.outcome: Cognitive functioning tasks will be presented and completed via a computer. A battery of 8 tests will include: Speed of Processing: Inspection Time, Simple Reaction Time, Choice Reaction Time, Short Term Memory: Word List, Immediate Recall, Working Memory: Digit Span Backwards, Attention: Switching Task, Speed of Reasoning: Odd-Man-Out Task. (see outcomes below)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.
baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.
baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Short Term Memory: Word List, Immediate Recall - computerised version of the Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT) (Rey, 1964)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Working Memory: Digit Span Backwards - computerised version of Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-IV) subtest (Weschler, 2003)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.
baseline and at 1 hr, 2 hr, and 3 hr post meal consumption for three consecutive days.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Blood glucose - using continuous glucose monitoring system (CGMS) (Medtronic, 2005)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Continuously from 0800h to 1330h for three consecutive days

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: children aged 10-12 years. Willing to attend on four mornings in one week of the school holidays. Willing to undertake continuous glucose monitoring. informed child and parental consent. Parent judgement about child's ability to complete cognitive testing requirements (e.g. ability to comprehend and sustain attention).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: currently on a prescribed diet of any description. Known allergy to dairy foods or lactose intolerant. Type 1 diabetes. Children with diagnosed learning difficulties. Children with diagnosed Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD).

trial_design.concealment:
Information session conducted and consent subsequently obtained.
Participants will be randomized to one of the three treatment orders via central randomisation by computer (www.randomization.com).

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) - Human Nutrition

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to examine the effect of dairy consumption on satiety and certain aspects of cognition (speed of processing, short term memory, working memory, attention and speed of reasoning) in a sample of primary school children aged 10-12 years. Primary outcome measures are post prandial glucose levels, satiety and cognitive functioning. It is hypothesized that meals with a lower glycaemic load and higher dairy composition will be associated with improvements in measures of cognitive function and satiety compared to a meal high in glycaemic load and containing no dairy food.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: CSIRO Human Nutrition Research Ethics Committee (HREC)
